Text: Praise the LORD. Give thanks to the LORD, for He is good; His loving devotion endures forever.
Context: The psalm begins with a call to praise and thanksgiving, recognizing God's enduring goodness and faithful love.

Text: Who can describe the mighty acts of the LORD or fully proclaim His praise?
Context: This verse reflects on the infinite nature of God's deeds and the challenge of fully articulating His greatness.

Text: Blessed are those who uphold justice, who practice righteousness at all times.
Context: The psalmist declares a blessing on those who live righteously and maintain justice, implying these are attributes valued by God.

Text: Remember me, O LORD, in Your favor toward Your people. Visit me with Your salvation,
Context: The psalmist requests God's remembrance and salvation, appealing to God's favor toward His people.

Text: That I may see the prosperity of Your chosen ones, that I may rejoice in the joy of Your nation, that I may boast with Your inheritance.
Context: Expresses a desire to witness and participate in the blessings of God's people, sharing in their collective joy.

Text: We have sinned like our fathers; we have done wrong and acted wickedly.
Context: The psalmist acknowledges generational sin, confessing corporate wrongdoing and a departure from God's ways.

Text: Our fathers in Egypt did not grasp Your wonders; they did not remember Your abundant kindnesses but rebelled by the sea, at the Red Sea.
Context: The verse recalls the Israelites' failure to appreciate God's miracles in Egypt and their subsequent rebellion, despite His kindness.

Text: Yet He saved them for the sake of His name, to make His power known.
Context: Despite the Israelites' failure, God saves them to display His power and uphold His name, underscoring His mercy.

Text: He rebuked the Red Sea, and it dried up; He led them through the depths as through a desert.
Context: Describes God’s display of power in parting the Red Sea, guiding the Israelites on dry ground, traditionally associated with awe and fear of God's might.

Text: He saved them from the hand of the foe; He redeemed them from the grasp of the enemy.
Context: Affirms God's deliverance of the Israelites from their enemies, emphasizing His role as Savior and Redeemer.

Text: Waters covered their adversaries; not one of them survived.
Context: Recounts the destruction of the Israelites' enemies, implying God's just retribution and the vindication of His people.

Text: Then they believed His promises and sang His praise.
Context: The people's response to God's deliverance is belief and praise, highlighting a moment of faith and worship.

Text: But they soon forgot His works and did not wait for His counsel.
Context: Indicts the Israelites for quickly forgetting God's deeds and not seeking His guidance, pointing to human fickleness.

Text: Their craving in the wilderness put God to the test in the desert.
Context: Details the Israelites' intense desires in the wilderness, suggesting that their demands tested God's patience.

Text: He gave them what they asked for, but sent a wasting disease among them.
Context: God answers the Israelites’ requests, but there are negative consequences, possibly highlighting the danger of desiring things outside of God's will.

Text: In the camp they envied Moses and Aaron, who was consecrated to the LORD.
Context: The verse describes the Israelites' envy towards their leaders, indicating unrest and discord among the people.

Text: The earth opened up and swallowed Dathan; it covered the assembly of Abiram.
Context: References a specific judgment event, where rebellious individuals were swallowed by the earth, instilling fear and warning against rebellion.

Text: Fire blazed through their company; a flame consumed the wicked.
Context: Continues to recount God's judgment on the rebels, this time through fire, evoking imagery of divine retribution.

Text: At Horeb they made a calf and worshiped an idol cast from metal.
Context: The Israelites' idolatry at Horeb (Sinai) is noted with disapproval, highlighting their betrayal of God with a man-made idol.

Text: They exchanged their Glory for the image of a bull that eats grass.
Context: It emphasizes the absurdity of idolatry, exchanging the worship of God for an image representing a common animal.

Text: They forgot God their Savior, who had done great things in Egypt,
Context: The verse accentuates the Israelites’ short memory and ingratitude, having forgotten the remarkable deeds of God that saved and sustained them.

Text: Miracles in the land of Ham and wonders by the Red Sea.
Context: Recalls the miraculous acts of God that went unappreciated by the Israelites, suggesting an attitude of indifference to God's interventions.

Text: Therefore He said He would destroy them—had not Moses, His chosen one, stood in the breach before Him to turn away His wrath from destroying them.
Context: Relates God's intention to judge the Israelites for their faithlessness, but indicates Moses' intercession, which prevented God's full wrath.
